Pp1-rK1J8KJ9j7jtdxYc2g.text: In Japan, they have the Ramen Museum, but it's pretty far away from the center of Tokyo.Here in Singapore, we're lucky enough to have Ramen Champion,which are the best ramen stalls form Japan imported into Singapore.The problem is, everyone has their own prefernces and unless you make repeated visits you won't be able to find your favorite bowl.My favorites are the white tonkotsu ramen at Ayoma (that serves the black soy broth). Its chicken soup is denser that Din Tai Fung's. Also, Bario is a classic that will fill up the stomach for sure.

7rtS_4DF1htkdA2lPGni4A.text: Ramen junkies, UNITE!So it's a one-stop variety show of ramen, Singapore style. Of course we had contests, and these are the champions... but who crowned them? Anyhow, at the original Bugis (Iluma) location, you can find six contenders, ranging from the hokkaido butter and corn style, to the tsukemen, and even jiro makes an appearance. I was a bit of a cop-out on my first visit, so I stuck to good ol' tonkotsu based Ikkousha, that also has the Hakata noodles that I nom with great delight. Tasty stuff. I've been back several times now, and enjoyed almost everything else, except Menya Iroha's Black Shoyu ramen, because either the queue is too long, or they're sold out, and... the jiro. I travelled 30 minutes by train once to try it in Tokyo, and as I ate it... I realised it really wasn't for me. A mountain of thick, doughy noodles, and the garlic? I couldn't finish. It's something to try though, so don't let my experience spoil yours. If you can, I'd say you're truly a champ.

FYLHXYZk-cEb3w-xoiJdvg.text: This could be my new favorite ramen place in Singapore. I visited it for the first time last week and I tried Bario ramen. It was advertised as a ramen for man, and it lived up to its expectation. I personally love hard, thin noodles, so I was a bit worried when I learned that Bario's use thick ones. To my pleasant surprise, the noodles were just heavenly. It was hard and chewy, and very 'manly.' The broth was the key; I love garlic and Bario's broth was just overloaded with it and you can even add some more extra garlic yourself. The char siew was not bad, nothing special. A tip: If you don't like your ramen with beansprouts, remember to notify the guy when you first order. The ramen comes with a ton of it and to me, beansprouts just destroy the texture of the ramen.Le wife tried the 2011 champion, which was Ikkousha. I tried 1 bite of it and I wasn't impressed tbh. But I think it's just because my mouth and taste buds were 'destroyed' by Bario's manly ramen which just overpowered Ikkousha's.I'll definitely be back and try all the other stalls in the future.

7NSbMVJe8CJz1RNVb1Ug-g.text: This is a place for you to get all the different types of ramen you need - buttery one ala Hokkaido style or ones with a spicy kick or the regular shio ramen, you have it all!I was pretty excited to have some of the ramen stalls in Singapore since I have been reading about these restaurants in Japan itself. I'm not too sure if it is just the scaled down version of the originals? The ingredients? The chefs? But be forewarned, you get very very mediocre ramen here. I come here when I feel like having ramen, just ramen and nothing else. Have your ramen with their lava eggs, those are good.I recommend having gyozas with your ramen too. Gyozas never fail.

JykWJoN3RswV_HHZ9cT4qQ.text: A kopitiam for ramen, seriously - a place where bunch of ramen vendors congregate. Nice idea to make the whole experience faster: you'll be given a bracelet that you scan when you order on any ramen counter that you choose and drink counter, give the bracelet later to the cashier to find out your total. It's constructed like a market where you can walk around and there're multiple stalls inside - I think you can find any ramen that you can imagine here, so you may have to visit this place several times to actually try all. It's a very nice idea since you can spend a whole day here trying different kind of ramen at 1 place, but our party don't find anything that taste really great.

6Wm0KjtPXwKcktQiC9cAcA.text: Meijin Don StallTendon ($13.80 + GST) - 3.75 starsThis came with lots of ingredients! 2 prawn Tempura, 2 fish Tempura, 1 pumpkin, 1 green pepper, 1 Japanese crabstick and 1 long bean. Seafood and vegetables! My favourite. The batter was a bit too thick and heavy and greasy though. Nonetheless, a pretty good choice if I'm in the area.Pork donMy plus one enjoyed this!

wbcPDxVHBSGg-YHXm0lbbA.text: Love this place, so many Ramen Stalls in one place so many delish options to choose from you can not go wrong if your a ramen lover.  Located in Bugis shopping center check it out!

zUNkI2xVhqNv_pu6UniZxg.text: Place is listed as open until 10:30pm however last order listed on their placard outside is 9:45pm. Closed sign is out front at 10pm. I think you should take a minute and figure out your opening and closing times. If last order is 9:45....put that as your closing time maybe? Just a thought. Whatever. Not coming back here.

lBWOsZJ7Ad-vw7tkmCWV9w.text: Not the first time dining in ramen champion. Their ramen are always good. Chefs are always generous with the food portion. Waiting time won't be too long. The prices are a bit higher of course but it's worth the money whenever you visit them. There's a lot of choices for you to choose from. From rice to ramen and also side dishes too. Definitely a Japanese cuisine lover to visit. Just to add on, they have free WiFi for customers to use too. It really is a nice place to dine in with your family, friends or partner here. Thumbs up!

xpbjySTqz-NO5I60gZ_6dw.text: This was quite a confusing experience. Firstly, the stores that many Yelpers mentioned in the reviews seemed to have been replaced? There was no Bario or Ayoma for eg. There're 6 stores in total, and you can see a list of them at the far right of the whole area. Secondly, there were so many choices and I couldn't really tell the difference between the different ramens. Which bothered me because they can't all be as good right? The staff of each store are also pretttttty aggressive as you browse, and keep asking you what you'd like to order. The ramen, for a store named Ramen Champion, was decent but substandard. and for the price of $15 for mine, I doubt I'll be back again when there are so many better options - even Keisuke Four Seasons at Bugis Village. I ordered the Hokkaido style black garlic ramen. Interestingly the thin slices of pork are layered around the bowl. The soup was fragrant without being overly oily and greasy. The egg was perfectly done, which I unfortunately can't say for some ramen places in Singapore...and the noodles were alright, the thin-cut straight noodles best known as the type at Ippudo. Overall it tasted alright, satisfactory, checked the boxes for decent ramen, but not something I would come back for. There wasn't anything particularly special about the taste of it, particularly the broth. I felt that it was a waste of calories, but oh well. Disclaimer: I'm picky about ramen and don't think it's worth eating unless it's really good.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Hokkaido style black garlic ramen

FvjjUtBOiTnNiIYe1tma-g.text: I must have looked like a newbie when I walked up to this place. One of the men working there was kind enough to explain the ordering process to me. Take a card, order your ramen and goodies, the stall scans your card and gives you a call button, grab a drink, find a seat, eat your food, hand the card to the cashier on the way out and pay. There are several choices a styles to choose from. I went for baisen shoyu. Extra egg for me too because I love a good soy marinated egg! I came a bit before the lunch rush because the place really filled up around me. There's free wifi and the password is on the wall by the drink stall. The food was great and the seating area is massive. This is a great place to come with a group. I'd come back in a flash.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Ajitama ramen with extra egg

st0LNA6pJbS9xV2D7s2p4g.text: So my friend and I decided to try out Mendokoro aoi after checking out the different ramen offerings at ramen champion.This is the shop front of Mendokoro aoi so look out for it! :) it can be quite overwhelming trying to decide what ramen to try at ramen champion.The ramen itself is very tasty, the noodles aren't very hard but yet still just a little but chewy. The soup is very tasty although it does have quite a lot of pork fat in it, nowhere as much fat as riki ramen I had in the ramen champion at changi airport. The char siew in the ramen has a lot of fat too so I went ahead and "de-fatted" the char siew. Not too bad a bowl of ramen :) I do like it! Although I still prefer walking across the street for my four season tonkotsu king ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Mendokoro aoi
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Shop front of mendokoro aoi

42-Sk1w472LfT5gygdQgcA.text: Thank you Yelp Singapore! So happy I found this place near our hotel.On the 4th floor of mall, a heavenly food court dedicated to Ramen! What?!Pros:+ 6 ramen shops, that competed at the Ramen champion contest.+ Easy pay, food pick up flow and plenty of seating.+ Buta God Ramen is my top 3 Ramen. 2013-2014 Ramen champion. I ate there 3 times.Cons:- They need signage on the ground level of mall so people know what's on 4th floor. Took effort to find.

sTqND9yIz4GCrij6jTlAtA.text: This place seemed to go for quantity over quality. The ramen I had was way too sweet, which I didn't notice until the third or so bite. It was weird.Whatever changes to my ramen I requested, such as not having an egg, were ignored.The seating is odd too. I felt like I should have carried my computer around with me because it felt like closer to a hawker center than a restaurant even though they technically assign seats.The gyoza from the ramen place on the right though was good.

47T2pLp_mRyCL7lbJOLDEw.text: I don't get this place. Most of the stalls are offering almost the exact same thing, and after trying several of them, I have not found one that I can consider to be very good. The price is not too cheap either.

dZUvcZ-72UDfiI7hPCgPjw.text: Love this place. There are many options of ramen to choose.Taste is authentic. I often go there when craving for ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Shodai Koji store. Highly rec to all

raivl0VWLwswVvfYHsdpIw.text: Want to have a nice ambience while eating your lunch or dinner? Make sure to stop by this place if you are at bugis+. The bamboo design makes you feel like you are in Japan itself.Like many of other yelpers had commented, there are a lot of varieties of ramens here. I was attracted to the Hokkaido ramen store as it has more crowds than the other stores. I ordered Hokkaido tonkotsu king. The egg was very delicious. The ramen was alright but the soup base was delish!There is a store for beverages too. Since I hadn't tried the Japanese fruit drinks, I tried Fuji apple berry drink. It was something similar to Ribena. Wanted to try the asahi draft beer but wasn't able to as I was driving later on. This is something like marche whereby they swipe cards and pay it when you are about to leave. The price of the ramen is rather expensive but it is worth to try. Will probably go back there once again if I'm craving for ramen :)

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Hokkaido King
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore

lqlzbRLnC-AsOtnJrFmC5Q.text: Tried out the best recommended ramen at Raman Riki. The soup is too salty while the pork meat is a bit hard. But the noodle is authentic which is good. The portion is huge tho. Dumpling is so-so.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore

vPA2bSTkuu7lnXWl27x5Vw.text: Two new popular Tonkotsu brands from Japan, namely Mendokoro Aoi and Tonkotsu Itto have been handpicked by Ramen Champion from Gunma and Tokyo respectively. We had quite a good start with the appetizers, Prawn Dipping Sauce with Cracker($4) from Mendokoro Aoi and Gyoza ($6) from Tonkotsu Itto. The Prawn Dipping Sauce tasted quite mild (didn't really have the prawn-like flavor), but overall it still tasted good with the cracker.The gyoza was pretty good, considering the fact that it specialize in ramen though I would prefer gyozas at Osaka Ohsho.Next up, one of the highlights at the food tasting, Mendokoro Aoi's Tonkotsu-Ramen Champion ($16.50) by Chef Kazuo Sakuraoka. The ramen presentation did reduce my excitement a little, however the white cloudy ramen broth was nice, light, flavorful. It does not contain the smell of pork bones. It's one of the lighter tonkotsu broth which I've tried thus far. If you love tonkotsu but don't like some of the heavier, oilier versions elsewhere, you might like Mendokoro Aoi. Perhaps one of the few minus points would be it was served rather lukewarm, not piping hot as I expected. The Chashu was slightly overcooked thus a tad too soft for my preference, though the thin layers of fat literally melts in my mouth. Well, at least the noodles were not too overcooked. Strangely, the Ajitama (flavoured egg) was under-cooked with runny egg whites. In contrast, Tonkotsu Itto's Special Tonkotsu Ramen ($16.50) (by Chef Yukihiko Sakamoto) is prepared in the traditional tonkotsu way where the pork-based soup is cooked for several hours to allow the essence of the pork bone to fill up the base. The ramen looks very appetizing (as compared to Aoi) and the portion was generous here, with big slices of tender Chashu conquering half the entire surface of the bowl. I felt a tinge of disappointment after tasting the broth though this Hakata style of ramen (albeit originated from Tokyo) boasts the taste of rich pork-bone tonkotsu broth with rather thin, non-curly, resilient noodles. Like in most ramen-ya,  the use of Chashu is not restricted to ramen. A pretty good side dish was Mendokoro Aoi's Chashu Carpaccio($7)--a sliced chashu salad garnished with tomatoes, onions and peanuts. Currently, the 6 ramen brands that we have are Tonkotsu Itto, Mendokoro Aoi, Menban Yamagishi Kazuo, Buta God, Gantetsu and Bario! For this latest battle between Mendokoro Aoi and Tonkotsu Itto, my vote goes to Mendokoro Aoi's for its broth as well as its springy, chewy noodles which were a notch above Itto's. I could not get used to the taste of egg noodles in Itto's version though its chashu won me over

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. mendoroko aoi

WYBJekSOg5QzF5TMS2aY2Q.text: I'm a Singaporean living abroad, back in Singapore for less than a week en route to Taiwan for a family holiday. Last night, after bidding some friends goodbye at the InterContinental hotel, I stumbled into Bugis+ having not been there before for a casual wander. Dinnertime approached, & I followed my nose up to the food area.Greeting me just around the escalator was the huge signboard claiming 6 ramen champion chefs from all over Japan. Being a huge fan of ramen, & on a personal quest to find the best ramen outside Japan, how could I resist? Here I reached a quandary; 6 restaurants, one stomach. What should I do? Do I roll a dice? Do I rely on the classic playground method of eenie-meenie-miney-mo? Should I phone a friend? Can I ask the audience??Wandering around lost, like a kid in a candy store, I had almost made up my mind based on some photos of bowls of ramen when the chef at Bario calls out to me. I tell him honestly that I'm lost for choice. He points at the standard ramen from his shop. Feeling a bit obligated, having been locked in a brief and polite conversation, I bite the bullet & go for the recommendation, even though the picture didn't look as appealing as the other one I was going to go for initially.5 minutes later, my buzzer beeps, & I collect my giant bowl of ramen, with a mountain of bean sprouts heaping from the top. I hate bean sprouts. Nevermind, I take an extra bowl so I can remove them. There is a lot of bean sprouts. A LOT. Did I mention I hate bean sprouts? I hate bean sprouts.The moment of truth, with most of the bean sprouts removed (because I hate bean sprouts), I stir up the noodles & ingredients into the soup. The aroma of garlic slices through the smoke, making me immediately forget about the heap of bean sprouts that I've just removed. I dip my spoon into the soup, & bring it to my lips. Thick, delicious tonkatsu soup. I approve. Next, the noodles. As I politely slurp a mouthful from my chopsticks, I am slightly surprised by how thick & firm the noodles are. I'm used to thinner, soggier ramen noodles. This was quite different. Different, but so good. I could get used to this.So the basics, the soup & noodles were pretty damn convincing. How about the ingredients? I pick up the solid brown egg, not really impressed as it looks like a regular tea egg. I was wrong. Before my teeth even met in the middle of the egg, I realised how soft the inside was. Just the way ramen egg should be. My vision blurred a little from the tears that were welling up in my eyes. I'm not even exaggerating. Time for the cha-shu.Oh my god, the cha-shu. Meaty, fatty, and soaked through with flavour. It's like I died & went to heaven & god is a cha-shu. With every mouthful closer to an empty bowl, I curse the fact that I was born with only one stomach, & may have seriously contemplated throwing up everything I ate just so that I could try another stall's ramen. I decided against, but guess what I'm having for dinner tonight? ;)

XVa7MPv5Q-jv9FtekYHM9Q.text: The reason why it's called a Ramen Champion is this: Each of the stalls compete against each other to tabulate their sales and votes at the end of each year, and the winner gets to set up a restaurant in Singapore. The question why would they want to set up a restaurant in Singapore is beyond me, we don't charge as high as Japan does... hmm... the only reason must be that Singaporeans love our ramen.The ramen stalls here have some kind of standards, they've got either pictures of queues pasted outside their counters, or articles gushing about their prestigious rankings in Japan. I felt the layout of the stalls was a little bit unfair, because it gets quieter as you walk towards the end of the place, and the two stalls at the back don't get that 'bustling atmosphere' in front. Well, regardless which stall you choose, the quality should be pretty okay. One thing I noticed is that their noodles are all about the same, the thick and yellow kind, not the kind of ramen I prefer. And they come in mega portions.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore

EUj86PoAh2F0geS5raeXkg.text: If you love ramen but can't decide where to get your fix from. This is where you head to. Though I have to warn you that after getting a table here, you're gonna me perplexed again at which one you should get. This is where all the good ramen gather and you're gonna find yourself coming back here to try them all.First off, the portions are pretty big and I really couldn't finish the bowl at all. But le bf managed to polish off both mine and his portions so maybe it's just me and my small appetite for carbs.The broth was really spicy and I would say that it was perfect for the slightly too cold air conditioning in the mall. I actually felt a little fuzzy inside and there are not many food out there that can give me that feeling.The star of this place is apparently the Menya Iroha's Black Shoyu Ramen but the queue is ridiculously long and I have no patience for things like that so I don't think I would ever try it unless there's no queue or whoever I'm eating with decides to queue.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore

RAZUlv4XN8IK3pKbXXmcPg.text: You listen to me really carefully here... IKKOUSHA'S Spicy Takana.Just do it.  We listened to a review on their FB account.  This is it.  Shiok

5GR4DMl5OIeY6JVik2PWyw.text: So, I went there for dinner with a friend earlier this week and for the life of me, I couldnt decide which ramen to get. After walking endless rounds I got tired and just ordered from the stall closest to where I sat.That happened to be the Aoyama ramen stall. I wasnt exactly blown away by it though. It tasted pretty average to me and I had to get my friend to grab me some garlic from the Bario stall so that I could add a little bit more kick into my ramen.The noodles were ok and so was the char siew. I also ordered the Gyoza. It was decent but not the best I've had.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore

4xa__iO3M4-_xuwHODMHog.text: 6 stalls of Ramen with varying tastes and styles to suit even the most discerning palate. I reckon this is as close or as good to authentic Japanese ramen can get, ramen from Japan that is. Anyway, I was there for dinner after work. The place wasn't too packed out, it was free sitting. You get a "credit card" like you would at Marché, because all the stalls do not handle money, you pay at check out.I had the tsukemen from Tai Sho Ken, it was not too bad. To be honest, it was my first experience eating that variation. A spicy soup for dipping your ramen into. It was good, portions were okay. Definitely give this place a try if you're in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Tai Sho ken!
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. One of the stalls here.
Photo of Ramen Champion - Singapore, Singapore. Tsukumen from Tai Sho Ken
